OSUWMC Clinical Practice Guideline
June 2024
Acute Asthma Exacerbations in Adults:
Emergency Department and Inpatient Management
What You Need to Know
•
Short acting bronchodilators and systemic steroids should be started promptly upon recognition of asthma exacerbation
•
Utilize RT-directed bronchodilator protocol for asthma exacerbations
•
Monitor peak expiratory flow (PEF) at baseline and subsequently to help determine severity of exacerbation and response to therapy
•
Patients should be discharged on a controller therapy and asthma action plan with close follow up
•
Clinicians can refer to OSUMC Outpatient Asthma guideline
What You Need to Know
•
Short acting bronchodilators and systemic steroids should be started promptly upon recognition of asthma exacerbation
•
Utilize RT-directed bronchodilator protocol for asthma exacerbations
•
Monitor peak expiratory flow (PEF) at baseline and subsequently to help determine severity of exacerbation and response to therapy
•
Patients should be discharged on a controller therapy and asthma action plan with close follow up
•
Clinicians can refer to OSUMC Outpatient Asthma guideline
An asthma exacerbation is an acute or subacute episode of worsening shortness of breath, coughing, wheezing, or chest tightness.
Determine risk and severity. Do not delay treatment.
•
RT evaluate patient; initiate RT-directed bronchodilator protocol for Asthma
•
Start short-acting bronchodilators promptly
o
Albuterol-Ipratropium (DuoNeb) shown to reduce hospital admission in ED
and pre-hospital setting
•
Recommend Prednisone 40-60 mg
o
Methylprednisolone IV 1 mg/kg (max dose 80 mg) can be used for severe
exacerbation or if not tolerating PO
o
No benefit from higher steroid dose
•
Administer/wean supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 90%
•
Regularly monitor PEF until clear response to therapy, plateau reached, or clinical
change
•
ED patients: determine disposition within 4 hours
•
Inpatients
o
Continue or step up home controller therapy with appropriate formulary
substitutions
o
Consider pulmonary consult for patient with moderate to severe
exacerbations or > 2 exacerbations in 12 months
Initial Management
•
Recommend measuring peak
expiratory flow (PEF)
o
PEF can be regularly
monitored until clear
response to therapy or
plateau reached
•
Consider chest x-ray if alternate
diagnosis suspected or no response to
treatment
•
Obtain venous blood gas
o
Consider obtaining arterial
blood gas if PEF <50% 
predicted, no response to 
routine therapy, or further
decompensation
•
Evaluate for complicating factors 
o
Anaphylaxis, pneumonia, pneumothorax
•
Consider alternate diagnosis 
o
Laryngeal obstruction, inhaled foreign body,
heart failure, pulmonary embolism
•
Determine patient’s fluid balance: consider dehydration 
due to poor oral intake, insensible losses
Factors for Severe Asthma and Risk of Death
•
History of severe exacerbations (ICU admission,
intubation)
•
Frequent ED visits or hospitalizations w/in past 12 months
•
Using > 2 canisters of albuterol/month
•
Difficulty perceiving asthma symptoms or severity
•
Low socioeconomic status
•
Concomitant psychiatric illness
•
Cardiovascular, other chronic lung comorbidities
Stratify exacerbation severity (mild, moderate, severe, or life-threatening)
Focused H&P
Testing
Dyspnea 
Mildⴕ
Accessory muscle use 
Wheezing 
HR/Pulsus paradoxus 
PEF % predicted or % personal best
SaO2/SpO2 on baseline O2 
With exertion; can speak sentences
None; increased RR
Often only end expiratory
Normal/None present
>70%
>95%
Moderateⴕ
At rest; speaking phrases
Retractions may be present; increased RR
Loud, throughout exhalation
100-120/May be present (10-25 mm Hg)
50-69%
90-95%
Severeⴕ
At rest; sitting upright; speaking only 
words
Subcostal, intercostal, or suprasternal 
retractions usually present; increased RR
Loud, biphasic wheezing 
(inhalation and exhalation)
>120/Often present and >25 mm Hg
<40%
<90%
Life-Threateningⴕ
Patient is drowsy or confused
Paradoxical thoracoabdominal 
movement
Absence of wheezing/breath sounds 
(silent chest)
Can be significantly tachycardic or 
bradycardic
<25% if obtained
<90%
Criteria

Mild Asthma 
Exacerbationⴕ 
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator
Protocol at Acuity Level 3
•
Prednisone 40-60 mg daily x 5
days (or IV equivalent)
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator
Protocol at Acuity Level 3
•
Prednisone 40-60 mg daily x 5
days (or IV equivalent)
Moderate Asthma 
Exacerbationⴕ 
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator Protocol at
Acuity Level 2
•
Prednisone 40-60 mg daily x 5 days (or
IV equivalent)
•
IV magnesium 2 g over 20 minutes 
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator Protocol at
Acuity Level 2
•
Prednisone 40-60 mg daily x 5 days (or
IV equivalent)
•
IV magnesium 2 g over 20 minutes 
Severe/Life-Threatening Asthma 
Exacerbationⴕ 
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator Protocol Acuity Level 1
•
Consult Pulmonology and prepare for MICU
admission
•
Methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg (max 80 mg) daily x 5
days
•
IV magnesium 2 g over 20 minutes 
•
Initiate RT Bronchodilator Protocol Acuity Level 1
•
Consult Pulmonology and prepare for MICU
admission
•
Methylprednisolone 1 mg/kg (max 80 mg) daily x 5
days
•
IV magnesium 2 g over 20 minutes 
Good 
response
•
Continued need for
supplemental oxygen 
•
Continued increased work of
breathing
•
Need for albuterol more 
frequently than Q4 hours 
•
Failed outpatient systemic
steroids 
•
Appears well but history of
severe exacerbations or
concern for further decline
•
Clinically improving but
requires albuterol Q4 hours
•
Peak flow < 70% but otherwise 
improving 
•
Economic barriers requiring
SW/CM evaluation
Consider one or more of the following status 
asthmaticus adjuvant therapies:
•
IV magnesium 2 g over 20 minutes
•
Administer albuterol 10-15 mg/h continuously
•
Use NiPPV if intubation not imminently required
o
Avoid if patient altered, encephalopathic,
agitated, or vomiting
•
Administer Heliox continuously (only in patient on < 
30% FiO2)
o
Give albuterol in line with Heliox
o
Can be given through NRB, HHFNC, or
critical care (e.g., Avea) ventilator via NiPPV
or IMV
•
Consider epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg SQ or IM
•
Methylxanthines (e.g., aminophylline) not
recommended
•
Consider intubation for the following:
o
Do not respond to adjuvant therapies or
NiPPV
o
Develop altered mental status or
hemodynamic instability
•
Consider ketamine for induction and post intubation 
sedation 
•
CAUTION: maintain a HIGH threshold for intubation;
involve Pulm/CC EARLY
Good 
response
Good response
Discharge (page 3)
Admit to appropriate level of 
care (LoC Guidelines)
•
Consider for patients with 
high-risk features or previous 
near-fatal event.
•
Consider PCU if requiring
frequent treatments/
assessments, or intermittent
NiPPV
•
Consider Hospital at Home 
for patients with improving
response
Admit to appropriate level of 
care (LoC Guidelines)
•
Consider for patients with 
high-risk features or previous 
near-fatal event.
•
Consider PCU if requiring
frequent treatments/
assessments, or intermittent
NiPPV
•
Consider Hospital at Home 
for patients with improving
response
•
Patients with 
o
Persistent respiratory distress 
o
Altered mental status, apparent fatigue or
exhaustion 
o
Continuous albuterol or Heliox
o
Continuous NiPPV, HHFNC or IMV
•
Normal PCO2 on blood gas is a sign of impending
respiratory failure. Pursue higher level of care
•
Discretion of ED, inpatient, and pulmonary/ICU
teams
Patient Admitted to ICU
Clinician discretion: 
Consider admit to ED Obs Unit 
or Hospital at Home
•
When evaluating “Good response”, can consider:
o PEF increase by >20%
o Ability to lie flat
o Decrease in respiratory rate by 10% - 20%
o Improvement in work of breathing/decreased accessory muscle use 
o Decreased in modified BORG dyspnea score
o Room air SpO2 >94% 
•
Antibiotics not routinely recommended unless concomitant infection suspected
•
Therapies can lead to further tachycardia and hypotension; consider
hypovolemia; give IV fluid resuscitation 
•
Avoid sedative, anxiolytic and hypnotic drugs: associated with avoidable death
•
Monitor electrolytes, especially K+; replace as needed
•
Lactate may be elevated in setting of beta agonist use
•
Consider inpatient pulmonary consultation for patients with slower than
expected clinical improvement, multiple admissions, risk factors for life-
threatening asthma, or clinician concerns
NOTES
Prepare for ICU Admission
Recommend early discussion with pulmonary consult/
MICU (page pulmonary/MICU fellow on call) 
Condition 
worsening
Discharge planning (page 3)

Incomplete
response
Incomplete
response
Poor Response / 
Failure to Improve

Discharge 
Discharge criteria –  
per physician’s discretion 
Upon discharge 
• 
Peak flow > 70% 
• 
Tolerating q4 self MDI with 
spacer 
• 
Off supplemental oxygen 
• 
Able to tolerate oral 
steroids  
• 
Improvement in pulmonary 
exam, respiratory rate, and 
work of breathing  
• 
Able to demonstrate 
appropriate technique, 
asthma action plan 
completed 
• 
Access to controller inhaler, 
reliever inhaler, and oral 
steroids 
• 
Discharge from ED/CDU or LOS <24 hours: Continue albuterol MDI with spacer scheduled q4h 
while awake for the next 24-48 hours, and resume PRN afterwards   
• 
Continue prednisone course for total of 5-7 days  
o 
Consider prednisone taper over 2 weeks for patients with severe or frequent exacerbations  
• 
For those not on long-term controller therapy, recommend initiation of inhaled corticosteroid 
(refer to Outpatient Asthma guideline). 
• 
For those on long term therapy, consider symptom frequency and step-up therapy (refer to 
Outpatient Asthma guideline) 
• 
Recommend patient education including asthma education, inhaler technique, and 
environmental control measures 
• 
Asthma action plan*** dot phrase in discharge instructions and reviewed with MD/RN/RT 
• 
If deemed high risk for readmission and delayed outpatient follow-up or no primary care 
provider, consider scheduled follow-up in 24-48 hours in Advanced Urgent Care Center 
• 
Close follow up with asthma provider within 4-6 weeks  
• 
Consider pulmonary referral if frequent exacerbations or uncontrolled symptoms 
• 
If deemed appropriate for Hospital at Home program, consider consult to initiate assessment  
 
Medications / Treatment 
Medication 
Dosing 
Adverse Effects 
Comments 
Corticosteroids 
• Prednisone (PO) 
• Methylprednisolone 
(IV) 
Based on severity (see 
guideline above) 
 
 
• Agitation/Delirium 
• Hyperglycemia* 
• Insomnia 
• Infection risk 
• Steroid therapy should be continued until patient 
achieves substantial symptom improvement or 
resolution 
• Steroid doses greater than those listed above have 
not been associated with improved outcomes in 
patients with acute asthma exacerbations 
• Early administration of steroids (<1 hour of ED 
presentation) is associated with a decreased need 
for hospital admission 
Equivalent doses 
• Prednisone: 5 mg 
• Methylprednisolone: 
4 mg 
• Dexamethasone: 0.75 
mg 
Magnesium (IV) 
2 g over 20 minutes 
May repeat dose once 
after 30 minutes 
• Nausea 
• Headache 
• Hypotension 
• No need to check magnesium levels 
• Caution in patients with severe renal dysfunction 
Epinephrine (IM or SQ) 
0.3 – 0.5 mg  
May repeat dose every 
20 minutes for three 
doses 
• Tachycardia 
• Hypertension 
• Arrhythmias 
• Rarely, inhaled beta agonists may not be effective 
in patients with severe bronchospasm; consider 
systemic therapy 
Ketamine (IV) 
See OSUWMC Pharmacy 
Ketamine IV Guidelines 
• Sedation 
• Increased 
secretions 
• Psychosis 
• Hypertension 
• Pulmonology/critical care does not recommend 
the use of IV ketamine in non-intubated patients 
with acute asthma exacerbations 
• Consider ketamine for induction and post-
intubation sedation 
Methylxanthines 
Discuss with clinical 
pharmacy specialist 
• Vomiting 
• Arrhythmias 
• Seizures 
 
• Literature does not support the use of 
methylxanthines in acute asthma exacerbations 
• Initiation should be done in conjunction with 
pulmonology/critical care 
Notes:  
See Outpatient Asthma Evaluation and Management guideline for guidance on OSUWMC formulary-approved inhaler equivalency 
medications.   
See Steroid-Induced Hyperglycemia Management guideline for assistance.

Quality Measures 
 
All patients with asthma discharged with rescue 
inhaler included on medication list 
 
All patients with persistent asthma discharged with 
controller therapy included on medication list 
 
PCP or Pulmonary follow-up arranged within 2-6 
weeks of an asthma related hospitalization

Disclaimer: Clinical practice guidelines and algorithms at 
The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center 
(OSUWMC) are standards that are intended to provide 
general guidance to clinicians. Patient choice and clinician 
judgment must remain central to the selection of 
diagnostic tests and therapy. OSUWMC’s guidelines and 
algorithms are reviewed periodically for consistency with 
new evidence; however, new developments may not be 
represented.
